captions.text:
It goes without saying that many of our most
precious resources are also the most limited.

Like, there’s only a certain amount of land
that we can build on, there’s only so much

gold that we can mine... and there’s always
the possibility of a bacon shortage.

And for some scientists, there’s another
commodity that’s in increasingly short supply.
Dinosaurs.

Over the last couple of centuries, we’ve
found thousands of dinosaur bones. But only

a limited number of species ever existed,
right?

So some paleontologists have been wondering
how many species of dinosaurs are actually

left for us to discover, and how many fossils
of them are out there?

Might sound like a funny thing for scientists
to ponder, but it’s really an extension

of a larger question that they’ve been wrestling
with, which is: How many different kinds of
dinosaurs were there in the first place?

Scientists who study living organisms deal
with these questions all the time -- like,

how many different types of plants and animals
are living in this forest glade? Or how many
microbes are in this petri dish?

Since they can’t possibly count every single
organism, they just count a small sample.

Then, they use statistics and probabilities
to come up with a mathematical model of what
that whole population might look like.

And in 2006, a team of biologists and statisticians
used these methods to estimate Earth’s population
of extinct dinosaurs.

Specifically, they wanted to figure out how
many types of dinosaurs there once were, as

well as how long it would take us to find
fossils of each.

Scientists usually count dinosaurs by genus
-- that’s the taxonomic rank just above

“species” -- because nine times out of
ten, there’s only one species of dinosaur
per genus.

So the team started cataloging how many dinosaur
genera had already been discovered.

Then they focused on how many of those genera
were really common, and how many were really
rare.

In many cases, for example, a dinosaur genus
might consist of just one known specimen,

like the cute and creepy Segisaurus, which
used to scamper around what is now Arizona.

But other genera were really common -- like,
you can hardly swing a pick-axe in parts of

America’s Northern Plains without hitting
a fossil of Edmontosaurus.

So, based on the abundance, or scarcity, of
known organisms, scientists estimate the diversity

of unknown ones as well. Or at least, they
try to.

And the results so far suggest that -- while
there are a lot of dinosaurs still out there

for us to find -- we may have less than 200
years of good dinosaur-hunting left.

As of 2006, the study concluded, we had discovered
just 29 percent of the 1,850 dinosaur genera
they think are out there, waiting to be found.

So, how soon until we find the very last known
genus of dinosaur?

Well, because of better techniques being used
in paleontology, we’re discovering new dinosaurs
faster than ever before.

The very first dinosaur fossil was identified
in 1824. For the next hundred and fifty years,

paleontologists only discovered an average
of one new genus of dinosaur every year.

But now, we’re racking up an average of
15 new genera every year.

And as a result, according to scientists’
calculations, somewhere between the years

2037 and 2056, we’ll have found 50% of the
dinosaur genera that ever existed.

You might think of this as “peak dinosaur”
-- at that point, there would be more known
dinosaurs than unknown ones.

After “peak dinosaur,” there will be fewer
genera left to discover, and the remaining

ones will probably be scarcer. So the number
of finds per year will start to decline.

But for a while, we’ll still be finding
them often enough to keep dinosaur-hunters
busy.

Between 2069 and 2102, according to these
projections, we’ll have found 75% of the
dinosaur genera.
By the mid-22nd century, 90%.

And by the year 2200, there will be only a
few genera left, and they’ll be harder to
find than ever.

At that point, even though there will probably
still be some surprise discoveries of new

dinosaurs every so often, those finds will
be extremely rare.

Basically, the golden age of dinosaur discovery
will be behind us.

However, these are just statistical estimates;
it’s impossible to know when you’ve ever
found the last of anything.

Plus, this timeline also only applies to dinosaurs
-- those reptilian land-dwelling diapsids

-- it doesn’t include all the other ancient
forms of life: pterosaurs, mosasaurs, plesiosaurs,
fish, mammals, invertebrates, and plants!

So there will still be plenty of fossils for
us to find, for a very long time.

And don’t forget, we’ll still have the
dinosaurs’ relatives -- birds -- to keep
us company.

Thanks for watching this episode of SciShow--
especially to all of our Subbable subscribers.

If you want to support us, you can go to subbable.com/scishow
to learn more.

And don’t forget to go to YouTube.com/scishow
and subscribe!

title: Will We Ever Run Out of Dinosaurs?

You say we are running out of dinosaurs. I say "Dig Baby Dig".

comments.author: Chris P

comments.text:
There's also the fact that scientists can't even dig for fossils in most 
places because they're either urban/populated or underwater.

And even barring the dinosaurs we're yet to discover, there's still what we 
still don't know about the ones we've already found. Most of the time, we 
only have bones to go on, which reveals only a fraction about what the 
animals were in life, and the vast majority of dinosaur genera don't even 
have a complete skeleton to their name. Scientists have only started 
learning what colors certain dinosaurs were in 2010.﻿

comments.author: David de Kloet

comments.text:
There are a few ways to calculate this. Rarefraction curves have some 
fairly major limitations, but it can be useful. You can also compare 
multiple museum collections (removing the specimens that are in both), 
treating them as random samples.

The real issue here is that we are limited to exposed material. One of the 
heartbreaking truths of this field is that you can be six inches from the 
most amazing find ever, but if it's six inches below ground surface you 
will never see it. I've nearly missed fossils because I almost didn't flip 
over a rock. Add a few kilometers of sediment (such as exists between the 
surface and the Mesozoic deposits in the Mojave valleys) and it's nearly 
impossible to find them all. Just prohibitively expensive.﻿

fossils (or at least one of each type of fossil) of dinosaurs that are 
buried beneath the earth's surface? 

But, you meant the question more in terms of statistical abundance of 
available new discoveries, which is a valid and useful question...well, at 
least for paleontology students.﻿

comments.author: Johnny Luken

comments.text:
+Cranopsis animals higher up the food chain-the ones with large body 
types-are more vulnerable to slumps in available energy. Think the 
dinosaurs. Vertebrates evolving to displace arthropods from their niche 
seems almost impossible whereas arthrpodods and marine animals having other 
available niches open for them is perhaps just a matter of time.

I don't think there can be any doubt that smaller animals are in a more 
robust position.

Maybe you're right about arthropods and cephalopods having biological 
limits (though less sure that holds over a billion year period). Can you 
elaborate?
comments.author: Johnny Luken

comments.text:
Things that do well in their niches can remain for long times. Sponges, 
coelecanths, ferns, etc. Your "theory" is not a theory and it doesn't hold 
with ecological predictions. Arthropods and cephalopods being poikilotherms 
really limits their versitility.

Not very likely...animals higher up the foo chain generally die off and get

comments.text:
Okay so wait, someone explain to me how there were so many different kinds 
of reptiles so long ago. Because my thinking is we should have discovered 
them all by now. If you consider every dinosaur to be a reptile and the 
fact that some flew, some swam and others stayed on land, there really 
shouldn't have been that many different types. Look at mammals today, some 
swim, some fly and the rest stayed on land, but I'm pretty sure we've 
discovered the majority of mammals that will ever exist. According to this 
video we may be discovering different types of dinosaurs for, maybe another 
200 years. That isn't including any we won't find due to their remains 
being in places we can't go, i.e. the bottom of the ocean. That's a sh*t 
ton of different dinosaurs. LOL! I could see God wearing a I love Dinos 
t-shirt in his lab just going crazy creative like this should have spikes, 
and this has a long neck, and this one has a razor sharp albeit ugly 
looking toe, and this one...﻿
comments.author: Brooks Adamson

comments.text:
Two different thoughts. The first: depending on how you classify animals, 
mammals count as reptiles since mammals evolved from reptiles, therefore 
large (particularly strange) reptiles are /still/ the most dominant 
(depending on your definition of dominant) form of terrestrial animal life. 
The second: dinosaurs of various types dominated terrestrial ecosystems for 
135 million years and finally lost that spot to mammals around 65 million 
years ago; in other words dinosaurs were dominant on this planet for about 
twice as long as they have been "gone" with only their descendants the 
birds remaining. That second idea should show why there are so many types 
of dinosaurs out there, you should expect there to be around twice, though 
that number is not guaranteed by any means.
